title: 111_s2940
content: The "Secure Airport Terminal Act of 2010" defines terms like "screening location" and "sterile area" according to existing regulations. It also aims to increase the use of security cameras at airports. The Secretary of Homeland Security must establish regulations within 180 days of the Act's enactment, mandating security cameras at all airport screening and exit locations. These regulations will also cover the maintenance and access to security cameras and technological devices by TSA employees for airport security purposes. The Secretary of Homeland Security may issue interim regulations regarding the accessibility, maintenance period, and permissible uses of data or recordings without following standard rule-making procedures. Improved monitoring of exits from sterile areas in airports. The Assistant Secretary of Homeland Security (Transportation Security Administration) must submit a report within 60 days of the enactment of this Act to specified committees, recommending security improvements at airport exit locations and assessing differences in configurations and options for enhancing security through personnel and technology. The specified committees are the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation and the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs. The Secretary of Homeland Security may prescribe regulations for security standards at airport exit locations, without following certain administrative procedures. Increased penalties for circumventing security screening will be implemented. Increased penalties for violating airport security measures will be enforced, with amendments to both civil and criminal penalties under title 49, United States Code. Operators of airports must display signs notifying individuals of the penalties imposed for non-compliance. The amended regulations require airports to display signs informing individuals of increased penalties for violating security measures, regardless of whether signs are present or not.
